body: These warnings have nothing related to the vert.x. And these are not errors.

@LinXiaoJian, I can help you with the Vert.x issue if you provide some sample code or more information about the issue but I'm not sure what mysql-connector-java has to do with Vert.x. They are unrelated and should not affect each other.
English only, please.

> English only, please.

2020-07-02 15:09:49,144 - org.apache.skywalking.oap.server.storage.plugin.jdbc.h2.dao.H2BatchDAO - 75 [pool-4-thread-1] ERROR [] - Data truncation: Data too long for column 'entity_id' at row 1

how do you solve this problem,please?

I think this is code level bug.
1. `EndpointRelationServerSideMetrics#entityId` 
1. `ServiceInstanceRelationClientSideMetrics#entityId`
1. `ServiceInstanceRelationServerSideMetrics#entityId`
1. `ServiceRelationClientSideMetrics#entityId`
1. `ServiceRelationServerSideMetrics#entityId`

Should add length statement in the Column annotation,  should be `@Column(columnName = ENTITY_ID, length = 512)`

Could you like to test locally? And send a pull request if the test passes?

@LinXiaoJian, unfortunately, those images aren't enough for me to help. Most of that code seems to be more custom than Vert.x idiomatic. Are you able to produce this issue in a project you can send me the source code for (via GitHub)? Preferably a minimally reproducible project.

I don't think Kotlin should cause the issue you're seeing.

@EvanLjp Please update the document.
I think there is NOT an agent side dynamic configuration mechanism. What do you expect?
i expect when application request amount is big，i can reduce  agent.sample_n_per_3_secs to ruduce  agent using resource

How do you know this is happening? I mean `too much traffic`, how do you know the baseline? and when to do this?
And when you want to change, which are the targets, for all instances of a service?
Then, how could you change and push the command to the agent? A possibility is `Dynamic Configuration Center` -> `OAP` -> `agent`.

And, there is a challenge is, when the agent reboot, it would be back to local static config, until the backend pushed the new configs. 

But, you mean, there is agent fail-safe protection mechanism, why do we need this really? Is there CPU overload for real?
